subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Macbeth
msgSnippet: Wow, Ewout!  This sounds excellent.  Is there anyone who can create such a driver for us? It sure would make using QS a lot easier. Shalom v Tovah, Jon
messageBody:
Wow, Ewout! This sounds excellent. Is there anyone who can create such a
driver for us?

It sure would make using QS a lot easier.


Shalom v'Tovah,

Jon
http://surf.to/frimmin

It is more necessary to love much than to think much;
always do that which impels you most to love.

--St. Teresa of Avila, The Interior Castle
----- Original Message -----
From: "Ewout Stam" <teraiten@...>
To: <Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com>
Sent: Friday, February 22, 2002 1:14 PM
Subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Macbeth


>
> -----Oorspronkelijk bericht-----
> Van: C. Paige Gabhart <pgabhart@...>
> Aan: Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com <Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com>
> Datum: woensdag 20 februari 2002 7:37
> Onderwerp: [Read_Alphabet] Macbeth
>
>
> >Following are responses to 3 recent posts.
> [snip]
>
> >Dear Ewout:
> >
> >I am going to need more help regarding your last post. It was not clear
> >to me exactly what this driver would do. The list which seemed to set
> >dh = Th ( I am working from memory here as I am picking up posts on 2
> >different computers). I thought perhaps you were explaining that if you
> >type "dh" you would get Quikscript output for "Thaw" or "They", and,
> >thus, you would not have to learn the Quikscript keyboard map. Please
> >advise.
>
> If somebody would create a driver, it can be programmed to return the
> 'they'-symbol when somebody types 'dh'. Two letters become one, but it
would
> indeed NOT require you to learn any keyboard map. You can just type a
roman
> reform and get proper quikscript returned.
>
> But someone will have to program this driver first. I certainly don't have
> the time/knowledge (yet) to do so.
>
> Ewout
>
